description: In a nod to local restaurants that have seen business and revenue plummet due to the coronavirus, the Woodland City Council approved an urgency ordinance that allows for outdoor dining. The ordinance got unanimous approval during a Tuesday night teleconference and comes after Yolo County approved reopening many businesses last week as cases of the...
text:
In a nod to local restaurants that have seen business and revenue plummet due
to the coronavirus, the Woodland City Council approved an urgency ordinance
that allows for outdoor dining.

The ordinance got unanimous approval during a Tuesday night teleconference and
comes after Yolo County approved reopening many businesses last week as cases
of the coronavirus stabilize.

Restaurants have been particularly hard hit by COVID-19. Because of the
pandemic, they were forced to close in late March and have been unable to
reopen, putting hundreds of people out of work locally and hundreds of
thousands out of work nationally. Some restaurants have provided take-out or
curbside service, but it has not been nearly enough to make up for lost
revenue.

In California, new health guidelines allow restaurants

to reopen but only under strict conditions. Many restaurants have been making
preparations to reopen but with diners spaced farther apart, as well as
checking the temperatures of patrons along with requiring they facemasks prior
to service.

The urgency ordinance is necessary because from a legal standpoint, businesses
are not allowed to expand their services onto public spaces such as sidewalks
or parking areas. It would also allow restaurants to serve alcohol in a public
setting, something not allowed under rules by the state Alcohol Beverage
Control board.

The goal of the ordinance is to help existing Woodland businesses and
restaurants expand their physical space so they can be compliant with state
and county public health orders, according to city officials, requiring
physical distancing while also ensuring that the restaurants and businesses
operate in a manner that is not injurious to the public health, safety, and
welfare.

The ordinance proposes a streamlined permitting process that requires approval
of an emergency temporary use permit by the Community Development director.
The director would have the authority to grant emergency temporary use permits
provided that the restaurant or business operates in compliance with all
applicable state and county public health orders, does not violate the
Americans with Disabilities Act, and does not operate in a manner hazardous to
the public health.

Interim City Manager Ken Hiatt called it a "good gesture toward supporting
those businesses impacted in our community." He said some restaurant owners
were already expressing interest since they "are the ones most constrained."

The amount of space would vary depending on individual restaurants but include
sidewalk space or a "couple of parking spaces" in front of or near a
restaurant. The specifics would have to be worked out on a case-by-case basis.

Hiatt said the urgency ordinance "would carry us through the emergency period"
and provide a grace period to demobilize. It could also be extended if needed.

Woodland Mayor Rich Lansburgh said he was a little worried about liability,
particularly if restaurant patrons were drinking wine or alcohol. However,
city staff noted businesses would be required to provide proof of liability.

Lansburgh said he understood but also wanted to public to understand that the
city was not giving carte blanche and permitting people to drink alcohol in
any public space such as a park.

He urged Hiatt to work with Police Chief Derrek Kaff to get the word out on
the Police Department's social media platforms. "He has more friends than we
do," Lansburgh said.

Councilman Angel Barajas said he supported the ordinance but wondered who
would be monitoring the physical distancing as well as checking for
violations. However, Erika Bumgardner, who is the city's business development
liaison, said that would be up to the city's Code Enforcement officers, who
would be checking.

Bumgardner said generally restaurants found in violation would be given the
benefit of the doubt on a first offense, particularly since both servers and
customers would probably have to get acclimated to the changes. However, if
there was a blatant disregard for the regulations, there would be a penalty or
fine.

The local ordinance isn't unique. Acting on Tuesday, the Santa Cruz Board of
Supervisors approved temporary permits to allow restaurants, retailers and
other businesses in the unincorporated areas to expand into their parking lots
for up to 180 days.

And like Woodland, Santa Cruz also waived fees for the permits.

Both Woodland and Santa Cruz officials also noted that dining, or shopping,
outdoors may lower the risk of transmission of the coronavirus while making
social-distancing requirements easier to follow for businesses.

Contact reporter Jim Smith at 530-406-6230.

keywords.text: risk of transmission of the coronavirus

title:
WOODLAND

Council allows restaurants to expand onto public property
html:
In a nod to local restaurants that have seen business and revenue plummet due to the coronavirus, the Woodland City Council approved an urgency ordinance that allows for outdoor dining.

The ordinance got unanimous approval during a Tuesday night teleconference and comes after Yolo County approved reopening many businesses last week as cases of the coronavirus stabilize.

Restaurants have been particularly hard hit by COVID-19. Because of the pandemic, they were forced to close in late March and have been unable to reopen, putting hundreds of people out of work locally and hundreds of thousands out of work nationally. Some restaurants have provided take-out or curbside service, but it has not been nearly enough to make up for lost revenue.

In California, new health guidelines allow restaurants

to reopen but only under strict conditions. Many restaurants have been making preparations to reopen but with diners spaced farther apart, as well as checking the temperatures of patrons along with requiring they facemasks prior to service.

The urgency ordinance is necessary because from a legal standpoint, businesses are not allowed to expand their services onto public spaces such as sidewalks or parking areas. It would also allow restaurants to serve alcohol in a public setting, something not allowed under rules by the state Alcohol Beverage Control board.

The goal of the ordinance is to help existing Woodland businesses and restaurants expand their physical space so they can be compliant with state and county public health orders, according to city officials, requiring physical distancing while also ensuring that the restaurants and businesses operate in a manner that is not injurious to the public health, safety, and welfare.

The ordinance proposes a streamlined permitting process that requires approval of an emergency temporary use permit by the Community Development director. The director would have the authority to grant emergency temporary use permits provided that the restaurant or business operates in compliance with all applicable state and county public health orders, does not violate the Americans with Disabilities Act, and does not operate in a manner hazardous to the public health.

Interim City Manager Ken Hiatt called it a "good gesture toward supporting those businesses impacted in our community." He said some restaurant owners were already expressing interest since they "are the ones most constrained."

The amount of space would vary depending on individual restaurants but include sidewalk space or a "couple of parking spaces" in front of or near a restaurant. The specifics would have to be worked out on a case-by-case basis.

Hiatt said the urgency ordinance "would carry us through the emergency period" and provide a grace period to demobilize. It could also be extended if needed.

Woodland Mayor Rich Lansburgh said he was a little worried about liability, particularly if restaurant patrons were drinking wine or alcohol. However, city staff noted businesses would be required to provide proof of liability.

Lansburgh said he understood but also wanted to public to understand that the city was not giving carte blanche and permitting people to drink alcohol in any public space such as a park.

He urged Hiatt to work with Police Chief Derrek Kaff to get the word out on the Police Department's social media platforms. "He has more friends than we do," Lansburgh said.

Councilman Angel Barajas said he supported the ordinance but wondered who would be monitoring the physical distancing as well as checking for violations. However, Erika Bumgardner, who is the city's business development liaison, said that would be up to the city's Code Enforcement officers, who would be checking.

Bumgardner said generally restaurants found in violation would be given the benefit of the doubt on a first offense, particularly since both servers and customers would probably have to get acclimated to the changes. However, if there was a blatant disregard for the regulations, there would be a penalty or fine.

The local ordinance isn't unique. Acting on Tuesday, the Santa Cruz Board of Supervisors approved temporary permits to allow restaurants, retailers and other businesses in the unincorporated areas to expand into their parking lots for up to 180 days.

And like Woodland, Santa Cruz also waived fees for the permits.

Both Woodland and Santa Cruz officials also noted that dining, or shopping, outdoors may lower the risk of transmission of the coronavirus while making social-distancing requirements easier to follow for businesses.

Contact reporter Jim Smith at 530-406-6230.
